what: Quasi Variances for Factor Effects in Statistical Models
title: Quasi Variances for Factor Effects in Statistical Models
text: qvcalc package provides R functions compute display quasi-variances often allow economical summary variance-covariance matrix parameters statistical model. Full package documentation, including version history, can viewed https://davidfirth.github.io/qvcalc . details statistical method, see references . install package CRAN (R):

title: Quasi Variances for Factor Effects in Statistical Models

Overcoming reference category problem presentation statistical models. Sociological Methodology 33, 1–18. http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.0081-1750.2003.t01-1-00125.x

what: Plot method for objects of class qv — plot.qv
title: Plot method for objects of class qv — plot.qv
text: Provides visualization estimated contrasts using intervals based   quasi standard errors.

title: Plot method for objects of class qv — plot.qv
code: # S3 method for qv plot(x, intervalWidth = 2, ylab = "estimate",     xlab = "", ylim = NULL,     main = "Intervals based on quasi standard errors",     levelNames = NULL, ...)

title: Plot method for objects of class qv — plot.qv
text: x object class "qv", typically result   calling qvcalc intervalWidth half-width, quasi standard errors,   plotted intervals ylab plot.default xlab plot.default ylim plot.default main plot.default levelNames labels used x axis levels   factor whose effect plotted ... arguments understood plot

title: Plot method for objects of class qv — plot.qv
text: levelNames unspecified, row names x$qvframe   used.

title: Plot method for objects of class qv — plot.qv

title: Plot method for objects of class qv — plot.qv
text: David Firth, d.firth@warwick.ac.uk

title: Plot method for objects of class qv — plot.qv
code: ##  Overdispersed Poisson loglinear model for ship damage data ##  from McCullagh and Nelder (1989), Sec 6.3.2  library(MASS) data(ships) ships$year <- as.factor(ships$year) ships$period <- as.factor(ships$period) shipmodel <- glm(formula = incidents ~ type + year + period,     family = quasipoisson,      data = ships, subset = (service > 0), offset = log(service)) qvs <- qvcalc(shipmodel, "type") summary(qvs, digits = 4) #> Model call:  glm(formula = incidents ~ type + year + period, family = quasipoisson,      data = ships, subset = (service > 0), offset = log(service))  #> Factor name:  type  #>       estimate     SE quasiSE quasiVar #>     A  0.00000 0.0000  0.2010  0.04039 #>     B -0.54334 0.2309  0.1127  0.01270 #>     C -0.68740 0.4279  0.3753  0.14081 #>     D -0.07596 0.3779  0.3239  0.10491 #>     E  0.32558 0.3067  0.2322  0.05390 #> Worst relative errors in SEs of simple contrasts (%):  -0.7 0.9  #> Worst relative errors over *all* contrasts (%):  -2.1 1.6  plot(qvs, col = c(rep("red", 4), "blue"))  ## if we want to plot in decreasing order (of estimates): est <- qvs$qvframe$estimate qvs2 <- qvs qvs2$qvframe <- qvs$qvframe[order(est, decreasing = TRUE), , drop = FALSE] plot(qvs2)

what: Quasi Variances for Model Coefficients — qvcalc
title: Quasi Variances for Model Coefficients — qvcalc
text: Computes set quasi variances (corresponding   quasi standard errors) estimated model coefficients   relating levels categorical (.e., factor)   explanatory variable.  details method see   Firth (2000), Firth (2003) Firth de Menezes (2004).   Quasi variances generalize improve accuracy   “floating absolute risk” (Easton et al., 1991).   device economical model summary   first suggested Ridout (1989).

title: Quasi Variances for Model Coefficients — qvcalc
code: qvcalc(object, ...)  # S3 method for default qvcalc(object, factorname = NULL,  coef.indices = NULL,       labels = NULL, dispersion = NULL,       estimates = NULL, modelcall = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for lm qvcalc(object, factorname = NULL, coef.indices = NULL,        dispersion = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for coxph qvcalc(object, factorname = NULL, coef.indices = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for survreg qvcalc(object, factorname = NULL, coef.indices = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for itempar qvcalc(object, ...)

title: Quasi Variances for Model Coefficients — qvcalc
text: object qvcalc.default, covariance (sub)matrix   parameters interest (including may   constrained zero).  generic qvcalc,   object can object relevant S3 method   defined.  currently include many types regression model   (via qvcalc.lm), including objects classes   coxph survreg;    also objects class   itempar. factorname Either NULL, character vector length 1 coef.indices Either NULL, numeric vector length   least 3 labels optional vector row names qvframe   component result (redundant object model) dispersion optional scalar multiplier covariance   matrix, cope overdispersion example estimates optional vector estimated coefficients (redundant   object model, example) modelcall optional, call expression model interest   (redundant object model call component) ... arguments pass qv.default

title: Quasi Variances for Model Coefficients — qvcalc
text: qvcalc.default method computational backend   , class-specific methods. qvcalc.default, none arguments   object used computing result.  remaining   arguments simply passed result object components   help record-keeping etc. qvcalc.lm, least one factorname   coef.indices must non-NULL.  value   coef.indices, non-NULL, determines rows   columns model's variance-covariance matrix use.    coef.indices contains zero, extra row column   included indicated position, represent zero variances   covariances associated reference level.  coef.indices   NULL, factorname name factor   effect model, used order extract necessary   variance-covariance estimates. qvcalc.itempar, "itempar" object must   full variance-covariance matrix "vcov" attribute,   must "alias" attribute TRUE.    attributes result use default arguments   vcov = TRUE, alias = TRUE   itempar function called. Ordinarily quasi variances positive square roots   (quasi standard errors) exist can used plots, etc. Occasionally one (one) quasi variances negative,   corresponding quasi standard error exist (appears   NaN).  fairly rare applications,   occurs factor interest strongly   correlated one predictors model.    indication quasi variances inaccurate.  example shown   using   data car package: quasi variance   approximation   exact (since type   3 levels), negative quasi variance.  quasi   variances remain perfectly valid (can used obtain   inference contrast), makes sense plot   `comparison intervals' usual way since one quasi standard   errors real number.

title: Quasi Variances for Model Coefficients — qvcalc
text: list class qv, components covmat full variance-covariance matrix estimated    coefficients corresponding factor interest qvframe data frame variables   estimate, SE, quasiSE quasiVar,   last two quasi standard error quasi-variance   level factor interest relerrs relative errors approximating standard errors    simple contrasts factorname factor name given coef.indices coefficient indices given modelcall object model, object$call;   otherwise NULL

(2003) Overcoming reference category problem  presentation statistical models. Sociological Methodology  33, 1--18. doi:10.1111/j.0081-1750.2003.t01-1-00125.x Firth, D. de Mezezes, R. X. (2004)  Quasi-variances.     Biometrika 91, 65--80. doi:10.1093/biomet/91.1.65 McCullagh, P. Nelder, J. . (1989) Generalized Linear Models.   London: Chapman Hall. Menezes, R. X. de (1999)  useful standard errors group factor   effects generalized linear models.  D.Phil. Thesis,   Department Statistics, University Oxford. Ridout, M.S. (1989). title: Quasi Variances for Model Coefficients — qvcalc
text: David Firth, d.firth@warwick.ac.uk

title: Quasi Variances for Model Coefficients — qvcalc
code: ##  Overdispersed Poisson loglinear model for ship damage data ##  from McCullagh and Nelder (1989), Sec 6.3.2  if (require(MASS)) {     data(ships)     ships$year <- as.factor(ships$year)     ships$period <- as.factor(ships$period)     shipmodel <- glm(formula = incidents ~ type + year + period,                      family = quasipoisson,                       data = ships,                      subset = (service > 0),                      offset = log(service))     shiptype.qv <- qvcalc(shipmodel, "type")      ## We can plot "comparison intervals" as follows:     ##   plot(shiptype.qv, xlab = "ship type")      ## An equivalent result by using the coef.indices argument instead:     ##   shiptype.qv2 <- qvcalc(shipmodel, coef.indices = c(0, 2:5))      summary(shiptype.qv, digits = 4) } #> Model call:  glm(formula = incidents ~ type + year + period, family = quasipoisson,      data = ships, subset = (service > 0), offset = log(service))  #> Factor name:  type  #>       estimate     SE quasiSE quasiVar #>     A  0.00000 0.0000  0.2010  0.04039 #>     B -0.54334 0.2309  0.1127  0.01270 #>     C -0.68740 0.4279  0.3753  0.14081 #>     D -0.07596 0.3779  0.3239  0.10491 #>     E  0.32558 0.3067  0.2322  0.05390 #> Worst relative errors in SEs of simple contrasts (%):  -0.7 0.9  #> Worst relative errors over *all* contrasts (%):  -2.1 1.6   ## Example of a "coxph" model if(require(survival)) {     data("veteran", package = "survival")     cancer_model <- coxph(Surv(time,status) ~ celltype, data = veteran)     celltype_qv <- qvcalc(cancer_model, "celltype")     summary(celltype_qv) } #> Loading required package: survival #> Warning: data set ‘veteran’ not found #> Model call:  coxph(formula = Surv(time, status) ~ celltype, data = veteran)  #> Factor name:  celltype  #>                estimate        SE   quasiSE   quasiVar #>     squamous  0.0000000 0.0000000 0.2023772 0.04095651 #>     smallcell 1.0012532 0.2535074 0.1501828 0.02255487 #>     adeno     1.1477130 0.2928805 0.2049427 0.04200152 #>     large     0.2301455 0.2772930 0.1991861 0.03967510 #> Worst relative errors in SEs of simple contrasts (%):  -1.7 2.4  #> Worst relative errors over *all* contrasts (%):  -4.1 3.1   ## Example of a "survreg" model if(require(survival)) {     data("veteran", package = "survival")     cancer_model2 <- survreg(Surv(time,status) ~ celltype, data = veteran,                              dist = "weibull")     celltype_qv2 <- qvcalc(cancer_model2, "celltype")     summary(celltype_qv2) } #> Warning: data set ‘veteran’ not found #> Model call:  survreg(formula = Surv(time, status) ~ celltype, data = veteran,      dist = "weibull")  #> Factor name:  celltype  #>                 estimate        SE   quasiSE   quasiVar #>     squamous   0.0000000 0.0000000 0.1852658 0.03432341 #>     smallcell -1.0831923 0.2405345 0.1537001 0.02362371 #>     adeno     -1.2162022 0.2743860 0.2022180 0.04089213 #>     large     -0.2627843 0.2745644 0.2024398 0.04098189 #> Worst relative errors in SEs of simple contrasts (%):  -0.1 0.1  #> Worst relative errors over *all* contrasts (%):  -0.2 0.1   ## Based on an example from ?itempar if(require(psychotools)) {     data("VerbalAggression", package = "psychotools")     raschmod <- raschmodel(VerbalAggression$resp2)     ip1 <- itempar(raschmod)     qv1 <- qvcalc(ip1)     summary(qv1) } #> Loading required package: psychotools #>                    estimate        SE   quasiSE   quasiVar #>     S1WantCurse -1.38337955 0.1400077 0.1427898 0.02038892 #>     S1DoCurse   -1.38338563 0.1400078 0.1427899 0.02038896 #>     S1WantScold -0.73070582 0.1306459 0.1328148 0.01763977 #>     S1DoScold   -0.55660577 0.1293742 0.1314680 0.01728384 #>     S1WantShout -0.24905230 0.1283297 0.1303847 0.01700016 #>     S1DoShout    0.69813569 0.1349252 0.1376080 0.01893598 #>     S2WantCurse -1.90929270 0.1534737 0.1571194 0.02468649 #>     S2DoCurse   -1.03672005 0.1341048 0.1364969 0.01863141 #>     S2WantScold -0.87273748 0.1320543 0.1343125 0.01803984 #>     S2DoScold   -0.11314599 0.1283548 0.1304310 0.01701224 #>     S2WantShout -0.18103325 0.1283049 0.1303675 0.01699569 #>     S2DoShout    1.31200512 0.1478902 0.1515414 0.02296478 #>     S3WantCurse -0.69552829 0.1303489 0.1324995 0.01755613 #>     S3DoCurse    0.04031978 0.1287445 0.1308728 0.01712769 #>     S3WantScold  0.51356595 0.1324282 0.1349026 0.01819870 #>     S3DoScold    1.33478884 0.1485182 0.1522130 0.02316879 #>     S3WantShout  1.35770834 0.1491611 0.1529003 0.02337851 #>     S3DoShout    2.87092053 0.2219058 0.2297809 0.05279924 #>     S4WantCurse -1.24501930 0.1373885 0.1399977 0.01959934 #>     S4DoCurse   -0.87273748 0.1320543 0.1343125 0.01803984 #>     S4WantScold  0.17794106 0.1294241 0.1316244 0.01732499 #>     S4DoScold    0.21263744 0.1296453 0.1318676 0.01738906 #>     S4WantShout  0.87109769 0.1378342 0.1407482 0.01981006 #>     S4DoShout    1.84022315 0.1654484 0.1702428 0.02898261 #> Worst relative errors in SEs of simple contrasts (%):  -0.7 1.3  #> Worst relative errors over *all* contrasts (%):  -6.9 1.4   ##  Example of a negative quasi variance ##  Requires the "car" package if (FALSE) {     library(car)     data(Prestige)     attach(Prestige)     mymodel <- lm(prestige ~ type + education)     library(qvcalc)     type.qvs <- qvcalc(mymodel, "type")     ##  Warning message:      ##  In sqrt(qv) : NaNs produced     summary(type.qvs)     ##  Model call:  lm(formula = prestige ~ type + education)      ##  Factor name:  type      ##          estimate       SE  quasiSE  quasiVar     ##    bc    0.000000 0.000000 2.874361  8.261952     ##    prof  6.142444 4.258961 3.142737  9.876793     ##    wc   -5.458495 2.690667      NaN -1.022262     ##  Worst relative errors in SEs of simple contrasts (%):  0 0      ##  Worst relative errors over *all* contrasts (%):  0 0     plot(type.qvs)     ##  Error in plot.qv(type.qvs) :  No comparison intervals available,     ##  since one of the quasi variances is negative.  See ?qvcalc for more. }

what: Accuracy of a Quasi-variance Approximation — worstErrors
title: Accuracy of a Quasi-variance Approximation — worstErrors
text: Computes worst relative error, among contrasts,   standard error derived set quasi variances.   details method see Menezes (1999) Firth   Menezes (2004).

title: Accuracy of a Quasi-variance Approximation — worstErrors
Accuracy of a Quasi-variance Approximation — worstErrors
text: qv.object object class qv

title: Accuracy of a Quasi-variance Approximation — worstErrors
text: numeric vector length 2, worst negative relative   error worst positive relative error.

title: Accuracy of a Quasi-variance Approximation — worstErrors
text: Firth, D. Mezezes, R. X. de (2004)  Quasi-variances.     Biometrika 91, 69--80. doi:10.1093/biomet/91.1.65 McCullagh, P. Nelder, J. . (1989) Generalized Linear Models.   London: Chapman Hall. Menezes, R. X. (1999)  useful standard errors group factor   effects generalized linear models.  D.Phil. Thesis,   Department Statistics, University Oxford.

title: Accuracy of a Quasi-variance Approximation — worstErrors
text: David Firth, d.firth@warwick.ac.uk

title: Accuracy of a Quasi-variance Approximation — worstErrors
code: ##  Overdispersed Poisson loglinear model for ship damage data ##  from McCullagh and Nelder (1989), Sec 6.3.2 library(MASS) data(ships) ships$year <- as.factor(ships$year) ships$period <- as.factor(ships$period) shipmodel <- glm(formula = incidents ~ type + year + period,     family = quasipoisson,      data = ships, subset = (service > 0), offset = log(service)) shiptype.qvs <- qvcalc(shipmodel, "type") summary(shiptype.qvs, digits = 4) #> Model call:  glm(formula = incidents ~ type + year + period, family = quasipoisson,      data = ships, subset = (service > 0), offset = log(service))  #> Factor name:  type  #>       estimate     SE quasiSE quasiVar #>     A  0.00000 0.0000  0.2010  0.04039 #>     B -0.54334 0.2309  0.1127  0.01270 #>     C -0.68740 0.4279  0.3753  0.14081 #>     D -0.07596 0.3779  0.3239  0.10491 #>     E  0.32558 0.3067  0.2322  0.05390 #> Worst relative errors in SEs of simple contrasts (%):  -0.7 0.9  #> Worst relative errors over *all* contrasts (%):  -2.1 1.6  worstErrors(shiptype.qvs) #> [1] -0.02099427  0.01563661

title: qvcalc 1.0.4
text: () Add aesthetic ggplot, alternative plot.qv()

title: qvcalc 1.0.3
text: Replaced URLs DOIs, function documentation references.

title: qvcalc 1.0.2
text: CRAN release: 2020-02-15 Added explicit method “survreg” objects.

title: qvcalc 1.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2019-10-08 Added explicit method “coxph” objects. Removed Suggests: pkgdown dependence, longer use Travis CI deploy documentation site.

title: qvcalc 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2019-05-09 Fixed minor bug plot.qv() Added example help page plot.qv, show re-order points/lines call plot.qv()

title: qvcalc 0.9-1
text: CRAN release: 2017-09-19 Reorganised qvcalc S3 generic function, allow others provide class-specific methods. package includes method qvcalc.lm linear generalized linear models. back-end computation now done qvcalc.default. method BTabilities objects now moved BradleyTerry2 package (version 1.0-8). Thanks go Heather Turner .

title: qvcalc 0.9-0
text: CRAN release: 2016-03-30 Minor tweaks fix dependencies NOTE CRAN checks

title: qvcalc 0.8-9
text: CRAN release: 2015-02-03 Corrects error calculation relative errors simple contrasts. formula used now agrees definition relative error given Biometrika paper. Many thanks Shaun Killingbeck spotting error version 0.8-8. Also made small improvements examples, cosmetic changes avoid NOTE latest CRAN checks. history starts version 0.8-9 (3 February 2015). Earlier versions listed .
